description: Small, soft-bodied insects that feed on plant sap. They can be green, black, brown, or pink. Aphids multiply rapidly and can cause significant damage to crops.
symptoms: Curled or yellowing leaves, stunted growth, sticky honeydew on leaves, presence of ants, sooty mold on leaves
preventionTips: Encourage beneficial insects like ladybugs and lacewings. Plant companion plants like garlic and chives. Regularly inspect plants for early detection.

description: Small flies that lay eggs inside fruits. Larvae (maggots) feed on the fruit flesh, causing it to rot and drop prematurely.
symptoms: Small puncture marks on fruit skin, premature fruit drop, rotting fruits, presence of maggots inside fruits
controlMethods: Use fruit fly traps with methyl eugenol
Bag fruits with paper or plastic
preventionTips: Practice good orchard sanitation. Harvest fruits at proper maturity. Use pheromone traps for monitoring. Maintain clean surroundings.

description: Tiny white flying insects that feed on plant sap from the underside of leaves. They excrete honeydew which leads to sooty mold growth.
symptoms: Yellowing leaves, stunted plant growth, sticky honeydew on leaves, sooty mold, white clouds when plant is disturbed
preventionTips: Remove infected plant parts immediately. Use row covers to protect plants. Maintain proper spacing for air circulation. Plant trap crops.
commonSeason: Hot and dry weather (March to May)

description: Moth larvae that bore into corn stalks and ears, causing extensive damage. They tunnel through the plant, weakening stalks and reducing yield.
symptoms: Holes in leaves, broken or bent stalks, sawdust-like frass near holes, damaged kernels, tunnels in stalks and ears
preventionTips: Practice crop rotation. Remove crop residues after harvest. Plant early to avoid peak borer season. Use biological control agents.

description: Small, soft-bodied insects covered with white waxy coating. They feed on plant sap and excrete honeydew, leading to sooty mold.
symptoms: White cotton-like masses on stems and leaves, yellowing leaves, stunted growth, sooty mold, wilting
preventionTips: Inspect new plants before introducing to garden. Maintain plant health through proper watering and fertilization. Prune affected parts.

description: Caterpillars that travel in groups and can strip entire fields of vegetation. They are most active at night and hide during the day.
symptoms: Irregular holes in leaves, defoliation, damaged heads of cabbage, chewed stems, presence of green or brown caterpillars
preventionTips: Practice early planting. Use crop rotation. Plow fields after harvest to expose pupae. Encourage natural predators like birds.

description: Microscopic worms that attack plant roots, forming galls or knots. They reduce water and nutrient uptake, severely affecting plant growth.
symptoms: Stunted growth, yellowing leaves, wilting in hot weather, galls or knots on roots, poor fruit development
controlMethods: Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
preventionTips: Rotate with marigold or other antagonistic plants. Use clean planting materials. Improve soil health with compost. Avoid moving soil from infested areas.

description: Small fly larvae that tunnel between upper and lower leaf surfaces, creating winding trails or 'mines' visible on leaves.
symptoms: Serpentine or blotch mines on leaves, white or brown trails, reduced photosynthesis, leaf drop, stunted growth
preventionTips: Use row covers to exclude adults. Practice crop rotation. Remove weeds that can harbor leaf miners. Maintain field sanitation.
commonSeason: Dry to early wet season (April to July)

description: Tiny, slender insects that feed by puncturing plant cells and sucking contents. They can also transmit viral diseases to plants.
symptoms: Silvery or bronze streaks on leaves, distorted growth, scarred fruits, black fecal spots on leaves, flower damage
controlMethods: Use blue or yellow sticky traps
preventionTips: Remove weeds and debris. Use reflective mulches. Plant trap crops. Maintain good air circulation. Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen.

description: Small moth whose larvae feed on cruciferous crops. Larvae create irregular holes in leaves and can severely damage young plants.
symptoms: Shot holes in leaves, window-pane feeding (membrane left intact), presence of green caterpillars, webbing on leaves
preventionTips: Practice crop rotation with non-cruciferous crops. Use floating row covers. Remove crop debris after harvest. Encourage natural enemies.
